docs.snippet: A couple of kitchen stocking stuffers:    The sleek stainless steel basting brush by Sili shown directly above does away with stray bristles and is a pleasure to use and a cinch to clean. The silicone ''bristles'' grab and hold melted butter or oi...
docs.abstract: Stainless steel basting brush and decorative little Nemo whisks would make good kitchen stocking stuffers; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A couple of kitchen stocking stuffers: The sleek stainless steel basting brush by Sili shown directly above does away with stray bristles and is a pleasure to use and a cinch to clean. The silicone ''bristles'' grab and hold melted butter or oil and spread it evenly. The brush is $11.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street).

headline.main: Whisk and Baster With Quirks, But They Work

docs.snippet: Shakoor and Marissa Watson, below, who own Shakoor's Sweet Tooth, 555 Throop Avenue (Halsey Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, have baked plenty of sweet potato cheesecakes (below right) and sweet potato pies, their signature desserts, for tho...
docs.abstract: Shakoor and Marissa Watson open Shakoor's Sweet Tooth, dessert shop in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Shakoor and Marissa Watson, below, who own Shakoor's Sweet Tooth, 555 Throop Avenue (Halsey Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, have baked plenty of sweet potato cheesecakes (below right) and sweet potato pies, their signature desserts, for those who might be caught short for Thanksgiving. They are open today from noon to 6 p.m., but are closed on Thursday.

headline.main: Southern Treats, by Way of Bedford-Stuyvesant

docs.snippet: Prolonging the taste of summer, a box arrives from Hancock Gourmet Lobster in Cundys Harbor, Me., via overnight express. Inside is a feast: fresh lobster meat and split-top buns, enough for six lobster rolls. Hancock also ships lobster pot pies, l...
docs.abstract: Hancock Gourmet Lobster in Cundys Harbor, Maine, sends by overnight express ingredients to prepare various lobster dishes; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Prolonging the taste of summer, a box arrives from Hancock Gourmet Lobster in Cundys Harbor, Me., via overnight express. Inside is a feast: fresh lobster meat and split-top buns, enough for six lobster rolls. Hancock also ships lobster pot pies, left, with a creamy sauce, chunks of lobster and buttery pastry in ceramic ramekins. I found the lobster meat for the rolls underdressed and added about a quarter cup of mayonnaise and some chopped celery. The lobster pot pies come frozen and need to be thawed overnight in the refrigerator before baking.

headline.main: Do-It-Yourself Lobster Pot Pies From Maine

docs.snippet: With their bulky shapes, whisks have always presented a storage problem. Now Kuhn Rikon has come up with two models that can fit in the shallowest of kitchen drawers.    The Easy Store balloon whisk, second from left, is held flat by a metal bar t...
docs.abstract: Comment on new designs in whisks; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: With their bulky shapes, whisks have always presented a storage problem. Now Kuhn Rikon has come up with two models that can fit in the shallowest of kitchen drawers. The Easy Store balloon whisk, second from left, is held flat by a metal bar that slides halfway down the whisk to collapse its wires. Slide the bar back to use. The Heart Spring whisk, left, has a coil on a swiveling handle. It skims over pans to whisk sauces, and then lies flat for storage.

headline.main: Reinventing the Whisk: Presto! It's a Pancake

docs.snippet: Masaharu Morimoto, right, lops off the top of his new beer with a saber, but don't feel obliged to do likewise. Mr. Morimoto, who was a star of ''The Iron Chef'' on television and is now executive chef and an owner of Morimoto in Philadelphia, has...
docs.abstract: Masaharu Morimoto, who was oen of The Iron Chef on television and is now executive chef and an owner of Morimoto in Philadelphia, creates two new beer and ale brews; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Masaharu Morimoto, right, lops off the top of his new beer with a saber, but don't feel obliged to do likewise. Mr. Morimoto, who was a star of ''The Iron Chef'' on television and is now executive chef and an owner of Morimoto in Philadelphia, has come up with two brews that have more to do with subtle grace than brute force.

headline.main: From a Brewer And a Chef, Ale Forever Amber

docs.snippet: Walk into Montrachet, 239 West Broadway (White Street), on a Monday night and you might think a party is going on. A party for wine lovers. Some customers even offer tastes of their wines to fellow diners. The members of the restaurant's wine team...
docs.abstract: Montrachet restaurant lures wine buffs on Monday nights, a normally slow evening, by dropping usual corkage fee and inviting customers to bring their own wines and share them with other diners; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Walk into Montrachet, 239 West Broadway (White Street), on a Monday night and you might think a party is going on. A party for wine lovers. Some customers even offer tastes of their wines to fellow diners. The members of the restaurant's wine team, including Daniel Johnnes, above, the wine director, ease corks out of 40-year-old Burgundies and decant first-growth Bordeaux -- all of them brought in by the customers themselves.

headline.main: Who Needs the Sommelier, Anyway? Just Try Wines From the Next Table

docs.snippet: Resembling a gaff used by a fisherman, the Pig Tail Food Flipper is a sleek tool for turning steaks, racks of ribs and other meats on the grill. The sharp stainless steel hook goes into the meat at an angle and pierces it in only one place, so it ...
docs.abstract: Pig Tail Food Flipper is sleek tool for turning steaks, racks of ribs and other meats on the grill; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Resembling a gaff used by a fisherman, the Pig Tail Food Flipper is a sleek tool for turning steaks, racks of ribs and other meats on the grill. The sharp stainless steel hook goes into the meat at an angle and pierces it in only one place, so it does not leave a mark or cause large losses of juices like a fork does.

headline.main: For Playing the Flip Side, An Assist From a Fisherman

docs.snippet: Chris Santos, left, and Peter Kane, the former owners of Wyanoka in Chinatown, missed the inventive quesadillas they sometimes served there, so they opened the Mexican Sandwich Company, at 322 Fifth Avenue (Third Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn. T...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chris Santos, left, and Peter Kane, the former owners of Wyanoka in Chinatown, missed the inventive quesadillas they sometimes served there, so they opened the Mexican Sandwich Company, at 322 Fifth Avenue (Third Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn. They serve 10 quesadilla combinations, on three layers of 6- or 12-inch tortillas -- plain, spinach, whole wheat or tomato-flavored -- with fillings like white bean and chorizo, barbecued duck confit or wild mushroom, $6.50 to $14. You can also design your own. Delivery is free ($10 minimum) from Fourth Avenue to Prospect Park, St. Marks Avenue to 15th Street.

docs.snippet: It's your restaurant, so should you fire the temperamental chef who's hurting business? Switch suppliers? Change the menu from French to American steakhouse? Redecorate the place, or relocate to Los Angeles?    For those who have always hankered t...
docs.abstract: Restaurant Empire is computer game that allows users to run virtual restaurant; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's your restaurant, so should you fire the temperamental chef who's hurting business? Switch suppliers? Change the menu from French to American steakhouse? Redecorate the place, or relocate to Los Angeles? For those who have always hankered to run a restaurant but aren't willing to invest thousands of dollars to find out whether they are good at it, there is ''Restaurant Empire,'' a new computer game by Enlight Interactive, a company known for its true-to-life simulation games.

headline.main: A Restaurant Run by a Mouse

docs.snippet: The place is called Pie but to call the pizzas it serves pies is a bit of a stretch. At the store, 124 Fourth Avenue (12th Street), the thin-crusted pizzas are shaped into oblongs, scissored into portions according to the customer's whim and sold ...
docs.abstract: Pie, on fourth Avenue and 12th Street, sells pizza by the pound; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The place is called Pie but to call the pizzas it serves pies is a bit of a stretch. At the store, 124 Fourth Avenue (12th Street), the thin-crusted pizzas are shaped into oblongs, scissored into portions according to the customer's whim and sold by the pound. It is a Roman idea, picked up by Jeffrey Reiss, the owner, and one that is already being used at Naples 45 in the Met Life building. But at Pie, there are more varieties, 26 to 30, in four categories defined by topping: cheese, meat, vegetable or dessert (Nutella, mascarpone). The pizzas are $5 to $10 a pound. Irresistibly crisp breadsticks are free for nibbling at the counter, and are sold in bags for $1. Pie also sells monster panini sandwiches and salads that come in bowls made of bread.

headline.main: Snip, Snip: Pizza by the Pound
